column5: This is exactly the scenario I anticipate, now.
Our family second place is in Charlevoix. We‚Äôre not going, and we were not planning to go at all this summer, but my MIL/FIL, SIL/BIL- they‚Äôll go this weekend. Because of course they will.
And she opened up first...the 2 places (MERC 6 and 8)  with the majority of second homes. I am shocked and surprised. We all know exactly what will happen this weekend.
Agreed. Increased testing does not mean spike.
Same. Am atheist, and same.
This. This.

I am in Michigan, and while I am generally a fan of the governor - I am actually getting angry at the incoherent and arbitrary pattern of what is allowed to be open. Automakers are open. Local retail/services  are extremely limited. Construction is open- and down the street from me- there are hordes of construction workers, not masked, working on houses. 

And the goalposts are shifting from flattening the curve- which we have absolutely done, to a vague set of numerics that change and don‚Äôt account for increased testing. 

I want to help do the greatest amount of good for the greatest amount of people. But I am starting to feel as if the rules are jello. I am frustrated with myself for feeling this way, but I am frustrated in general. Gah.
Never, actually. I‚Äôm reasoned, calm, and know history. That‚Äôs why I object to using the word slavery in the state of Michigan to describe the current order.

Slave is not hate speech. I didn‚Äôt say that it was. I said that using slavery to describe the safer at home acts is wrong. 

Thanks for reading.

I‚Äôm in Michigan. And that‚Äôs untrue. The areas are open now- and you could always buy those things- you just had to plan ahead and call for pickup, when the areas were blocked. It required thinking ahead for non food purchases. It was easy to procure the items during that time. 

It‚Äôs fine. We aren‚Äôt going to agree. I think you do yourself no favors with your comparison, but of course, you are free to make them. I‚Äôm free to ignore them, as I will now. 

Just remember- I agree that there‚Äôs been an overreaction. I just see no reason for hyperbole.

That is not this situation, and hyperbole does not help you make your case.

For the record- I think the lockdown is a complete overreaction not based on evidence. I agree with the premise you are objecting to. Perhaps think about why extremes that do not apply weaken, rather than strengthen, your position.
I‚Äôm not hurt. Just hopeful. There‚Äôs a difference.
Because that is not true. Come on.

I am like that. We should all be like that. There are ways to say that without using that terminology, and frankly, it‚Äôs low expectations on the comment to not use a better term. Do better. Be better.

In the forum, in this discussion alone, people used the r word and referred to the stay at home order as slavery, called her a gendered insult, and invoked Hitler.  

I know the people having thoughtful discussions on here can do better. I come here for positive discussions, evidence based information, and thoughtful commentary. These distractions are unnecessary, and undercut the goals.

She doesn‚Äôt want to be VP. I am a Dem, a Whitmer voter, donor and volunteer. The VP talk is conjecture, not reality. 

Thanks for listening.

Hi. She doesn‚Äôt want to be Veep. It‚Äôs a false narrative. She‚Äôs not auditioning, she‚Äôs not trying to prove anything to Biden. She‚Äôs a born and bred Michigander, and she wants to stay here. Her daughters are in school here, and being VP is not her goal.

None of that matters with her, and she‚Äôs been clear. 

I do believe she had overreached, and I do hope there is success in stopping it. But it‚Äôs not about being VP.
Please don‚Äôt use that word. Thanks.

Totally. This forum has some people describing the party they don‚Äôt belong to, and it‚Äôs unwelcoming. Why are we doing this? What does it help? Conjecture about why I‚Äôm a liberal, and a list of all the reasons I suck for it-as supposed by some people who are just being partisan- what does that advance? And the reverse. It‚Äôs disappointing. 

We should be better than this. I hope we can be.
It is not. That is a function of testing, inadequate testing, not the actual IFR. It is not a fatality rate of 14.5, because the denominator is unknown. You can‚Äôt do partial math.
Thank you for this. Yes.
I‚Äôm a liberal. And no. To all of the above.
I tried one pair of underwear last summer from them. Immediately ordered all new underwear and tossed every last pair I had before then. ü§£ü§£

My FIL was inpatient for cath lab and monitoring last week- he said he felt very safe, and he saw nothing that alarmed him, and every person he came in contact with was cautious and careful. He was swabbed for the virus, in advance. 

Your dad will be okay. He‚Äôll be safe.
Yes. Yes. The age ranges are too broad.
Holy wow!!! That is awful!
This. This. This.

So I have a family of six, and a business. We bought masks for all of our employees , and a week‚Äôs worth of masks for our family- so from varying vendors- we‚Äôve purchased close to 100 cloth masks. Some from Etsy- and those are great. But my two faves are :


https://lamadeclothing.com/


https://losangelesapparel.net/products/3-pack-cotton-mask

Shipping is swift. They wash easily. They have multiple patterns available. They fit everyone- and are adjustable in all the right ways. 

I hope that helps.
THIS.
I think it‚Äôs very hard to tell at this point. My guess is some, but not all.
My best answer is - magic math. ü§£ü§£

Not that I am aware of for public access. Which is, you know, part of the problem. Sorry I cannot be more specific, I know there are tangential papers available at Cochrane- that mention these issues, specifically some of Jefferson‚Äôs lead studies on flu vaccine efficacy. Their sourcing is top notch- and maybe some of their cites lead back to accessible sourcing for you?  https://www.cochrane.org/welcome

I‚Äôm sure you saw this- this is their public facing page at the CDC on how they do it, but they leave out the methodology for some of the numbers, which is what creates the issue, as well as, they don‚Äôt confirm to the degree they should after, which is why we hear the myth of 80k. https://www.cdc.gov/flu/about/burden/how-cdc-estimates.htm

They have a mathematical formula they base on diagnosed/ probable cases and expand it to cover the population.  It‚Äôs a guess, and it wildly favors overestimation. ETA: so basically, same for both. Some confirmation on both, they take off from there

So- the super brief explanation of excess death is a number of deaths above the expected period of time. Let‚Äôs pretend in January, in Michigan- 4 deaths total were expected, and that‚Äôs the average. And we look back and see 6. The extra 2 are excess, and we have to decide what they are from. I‚Äôm going to link an article from Reason magazine here, that does a great job of explaining it in context with Covid. 

In my opinion- excess deaths is a metric that can look really scary, but it does not necessarily indicate that one particular thing is causing it- and especially in the case of Covid, where treatment for other conditions are falling by the wayside. 

I hope that helps. I‚Äôm happy to take another pass at it if I am being unclear https://reason.com/2020/04/29/what-excess-deaths-do-and-dont-tell-us-about-covid-19/
1984 meets Andromeda Strain. That is absolutely perfect description. Yes!!!

How about reading this- a million years ago, in my job, I came across this letter. And the things in this letter- this is what changed my once set in stone ways- and made me start to question what I‚Äôd been told to trust as absolute authority. I apologize for the out of date of this link, except the underlying premises and complaints listed here- those are all still true. 


https://aspe.hhs.gov/cdc-%E2%80%94-influenza-deaths-request-correction-rfc

It means they do not have testing that confirms the presence of the virus in that case. It‚Äôs a weakness in methodology- and has been present for decades, and in my opinion- it is wrong to do. A way to look at it- when a Covid test is administered- decided upon by a medical authority that it is necessary- the percentage of those tests that pop positive are still far from ubiquitous positives. And that‚Äôs within a population suspected to have it, at the time of the test order. Extrapolate that premise to the way mortality is calculated- which is what the CDC has been doing for a very long time. Lumping all sorts of causes together, not properly dividing and identifying, and we get a result where we are supposed to believe 80k people die from flu infection that would be prevented from a shot. And that‚Äôs just not it at all.

ETA: to your question about the data of Covid, Covid + another condition-  that‚Äôs an attempt to show multiple probable factors in a death. The intent is good- but not when they are umbrella-d together under a too large umbrella. In my opinion- it‚Äôs a case of trying to answer too many questions with not enough data. Basically- an association with a condition is not proof of underlying causation of a death.

Basically- the CDC uses indirect modeling and fails to make the distinction between actual confirmed flu deaths, and a broad category of flu associated deaths, which also brings in a large cohort of pneumonias which have over 30 possible causes- including stomach acid. The problem is that makes the numbers far larger than they actually are- and exaggerates threats in the wrong directions. So when we hear that 80k people died of the flu? No. No. No. That‚Äôs absolutely not the case. That is also what we are seeing here, in this situation. 

Does that help? This is the point where my spouse‚Äôs eyes glaze over and he looks for an escape. ü§£ü§£
Absolutely agree. ( I have an immunology degree- so I understand what we‚Äôre seeing, and have been for years, and it just fuels my rage, most of the time. Sigh.)
The CDC has driven me mad with anger for years over their flu mortality models( which are absolute crap). This whole situation is not helping dissipate that anger.
As mass overreaction.
Samesies

This was driving me insane- of course there‚Äôs a recovery period! I never understood why no one stood up and said anything to push back! 

And now the military has restrictions based on it. Faulty information. Mind boggling.

But this is bizarre behavior, from you. Complaining about a man not campaigning in 2020- when he‚Äôs not in an election for 2020. What? ( and will keep downvoting you because you keep talking about itü§£)

Look- criticize his response. I have zero issue with that, and actually agree. But there‚Äôs zero reason to lie about things like this to bolster your argument. You hurt your position when you undercut it.
Oh. That is verifiably not true. The man ran a campaign. And was elected.
What? Newsom won his election, and did run for office.  What does your comment even mean?

I completely understand this. I just don‚Äôt understand how or why they lie, but clearly, come on. I did get brave enough with one person to say something, but she was so obviously a fraud it wasn‚Äôt much of a ripple.

I know one family, they are fully recovered now, and had mild illnesses- parents are 50, kids are 24 and 19. The dad and the daughter both worked in the Bronx, so they were in the epicenter. 

I think we have now overreacted, and the numbers/outcomes do not support the level of lockdown. I have no problem wearing a mask, or social distancing. But I‚Äôm in a state that has extended lockdown twice now and I‚Äôm unsure what the end game is now. 

What amazes me is how everyone on Twitter claims to have multiple relatives that have died from it. Statistically- I do not understand how it would be possible, considering overall numbers of both diagnoses and the percentage of people on Twitter in general population.
There was no surge in my area.

Listen. He/she/they was super aggressive for no reason- then spit back out data that supports the original point. Like, what even? 

If downvotes happens from that, so be it. It‚Äôs not because of data- it‚Äôs because of interactions. Which do matter.

One hundred percent this. 

I also think she is a secret shill for Big Tumeric. If that‚Äôs a thing. ü§£ü§£

I know all of the above. You asked for a link/source for the .1 - which I gave you, from 3 academic sources. The point is- all of this talk of IFR leads the same way- the overall IFR is far lower than is currently being bandied about, and of course, risk is stratified by population. 

Have a good day.

No. This is untrue. There are people who were swabbed positives who test negative with Abbott. Your doctor is wrong. Twitter has threads of these people- and I reposted one of them yesterday.

Edited to add: https://twitter.com/DanaGoldstein/status/1257712971469541377?s=20

The antibody tests are not all they‚Äôve cracked up to be- and evidence of infection can be detected in many possibly paths. Antibody testing may not be the way to go- and in the both the Roche testing and the Abbott testing the Ns are ridiculously low. 

My husband had the antibody test- it was negative- and his doctor was like- yeah, whatever, you had it. We‚Äôll just have to wait until they figure the testing out.
Absolutely. It‚Äôs hard to keep track of it all- and honestly- you meant absolutely no harm. I get why you were frustrated. Completely.
Here you go: https://twitter.com/danagoldstein/status/1257712971469541377?s=21

Gently, you were in the wrong. That‚Äôs okay, we all do the best we can, and this situation is stressful, and has been going on for a long time. But in a shared space, you should have worn a mask. And I‚Äôm sure you will next time.

Have a good day, and I hope you find some peace in your friendship. You want pick a fight that isn‚Äôt here, instead of perhaps realizing I wasn‚Äôt even replying to you, in the thread, and instead, you‚Äôre criticizing a grammatical convention I made in a reply to someone else.

There was an interesting thread on Twitter with people who had confirmed Covid- PCR from swab during their infections, and they are negative on the antibody test.  That being said- my spouse had the antibody test (Abbott) and it was negative. And his doctor is absolutely convinced he had it.

You saved me the typing. This is exactly correct. Yes. And the newspapers running with it aren‚Äôt super careful with explaining the incidence of it, and in my opinion, they cause more fear. We need to be aware, to take care, and to follow best practices, but no,strokes are still a rare complication.

This is critical to remember. The stories are highlighting a tiny subset of super rare complications, and it makes everything seem out of proportion. Yes. There are risks. We should absolutely be cautious and follow guidelines. But at the end of the day- the vast vast majority of people who contract this illness have an uncomplicated recovery. Even in the most at risk populations- that is true.
